The photographer James Oatway captures the attack on Emmanuel Sithole in Johannesburg which took less than two minutes and ends with the attacker's arrest. The attack has led to seven deaths and xenophobic violence against poorer immigrants is still ongoing. Oatway's photos of the attack have captured the level of depravity rarely seen in South Africa and the photographer is sickened and angry.

The Catholic Church in America is blasting the new BBC drama Wolf Hall for its portrayals of the religious turmoil in Tudor England. The review attacking the series as "a work of fiction that adopts a narrow, revisionist and anti-Catholic point of view toward the religious turmoil of the Tudor period" echoes similar criticisms made by UK clergy.

A blind man was left 'completely embarrassed and humiliated' after staff at his local Post Office refused him entry with his guide dog. Craig Roberts, 36, from Chadderton, Manchester, walked into his town's Post Office and an employee shouted from behind the counter that he would have to leave his guide dog Bruce outside if he wanted to be served. Even when Mr Roberts explained his two-year-old Golden Labrador Retriever Cross was a guide dog, the employee allegedly still insisted he should be left outside.

Freddie Gray, a 25-year-old man who was arrested and died after suffering a spinal injury, was the focus of protests and violence in Baltimore Saturday night. At least five police cars were damaged and 12 people were arrested. Some protesters threw objects at police and got into physical altercations, while others marched through the city. The event ended after speeches at City Hall.

The 50-year-old former TV and radio presenter, from Marton, Middlesbrough, Dave Roberts, has bungee jumped off the Transporter Bridge over the River Tees 100 years after his ancestor jumped to his death for a bet worth just a sixpence. Mr Roberts, who hopes to become the mayor of Middlesbrough, has survived the jump which he carried out for a children's charity.

Nasa has unveiled a revolutionary type of wing that it says could save millions in air travel. The wing is able to morph itself like that of a bird to provide the same functionality as normal flaps, but with much less weight. It can also reportedly be used to increase fuel efficiency and even reduce noise on take-off and landing.

Manchester City manager Manuel Pellegrini has come under fire following their title race capitulation. However, dismal defeats at Burnley and Crystal Palace have placed serious question marks about Pellegrini's ability to motivate his top players.

Superfoods are foods that have powerful nutritional benefits, and today we're discussing some of the best ones. Tart cherries, avocado, cranberries, blueberries and pumpkin seeds are all high in antioxidants and vitamins and minerals, and are therefore thought to have a wide range of health benefits. be careful where you get your intake of these foods, as they can also be high in sugar.

Gary Dahl, the creator of the Pet Rock, has died aged 78 in southern Oregon. His Pet Rock, which was simply a common everyday stone, came with a manual which, tongue in cheek, detailed how the owner should take care of it. The Pet Rock craze 'was great fun when it happened,' his wife recalled in a telephone interview. However, over time, 'people would come to him with weird ideas, expecting him to do for them what he had done for himself. And a lot of times they were really, really stupid ideas.'

After 21-year-old Eloise Aimee Parry swallowed eight pills containing the toxic chemical 2,4-Dinitrophenol (DNP), she "burned up from within." Her mother, 51, discovered the pills in her daughter's bag after her death in hospital. DNP is a pesticide used to suppress plant growth and has been linked to at least 62 deaths worldwide. Despite the dangers, the drug can be bought cheaply and easily online.

Eleven football fans have had their death sentences upheld after a retrial over a stadium riot in Egypt which left 74 people dead. The riot erupted in February 2012 when supporters of home team Al-Masry - from the canal city of Port Said - and Cairo's Al-Ahly clashed after an Egyptian league match between the two clubs. An appeals court ordered the retrial of 73 defendants last year after rejecting a lower court's verdict, which sentenced 21 people to death. Today, eleven of the fans were again sentenced to death, with their verdicts referred to Egypt's supreme court, the Grand Mufti. The court will make a final decision on their fates, as well as those of the other defendants, on May 30. The 73 defendants include nine police officers and three officials from Al-Masry club, while the rest were fans of the team. Two of those sentenced to death are on the run. None of the families of the victims or of the defendants attended today's court session, which was held in Cairo for security reasons. The clashes in the Port Said stadium sparked days of violent protests in Cairo, in which another 16 people were killed in fighting with security forces. According to Google Politics, the most popular questions typed into the search engine about 2016 presidential candidates were about candidates' ages and heights. The most popular question was asking how old Clinton is. The second-most popular was asking how tall Rubio is. Interest in both Clinton and Rubio seemed to be on the rise as of Sunday after they said they were running.

Army officer and his wife admit assaulting hotel guests and workers after getting drunk at their own wedding reception. The couple were spared jail after a court heard that they were too drunk to remember what they had done.

The author of the article describes a trip offered by a company called Natural World Safaris that allows tourists to sleep in the natural habitat of the Siberian tiger, one of the world's most endangered animals. The trip is offered for a price of £3,500 and is limited in quantity. The trip is described as one of the rarest wildlife travel opportunities remaining today and offers guests the chance to track the movements of the tigers in the area.

Authorities are searching for Kamron Taylor, who escaped from a jail in Illinois early Wednesday morning after attacking a correctional officer. Taylor was convicted of murder in a botched robbery in 2009, and authorities believe he escaped because he was wearing the officer's uniform.

The article explores the discovery of a Nazi magazine from the 1930s featuring pictures of Adolf Hitler in comical poses, including one of him balancing on the edge of a log cabin veranda. These photos were later used to promote Hitler's image to the Nazi faithful. Despite the ridiculous vanity of the photos, they are a compelling read thanks to the lyrical prose of the author's fawning.

Researchers studying the long-term effects of hormone replacement therapy (HRT) have found that while the therapy may reduce a woman's risk of heart disease and osteoporosis, it continues to increase her risk of breast cancer. Although this risk is only 'a little more risk than we thought,' women should still be cautious about using HRT.

Rudi Austin was sent off in the first half and Blackburn won 3-0. Austin elbowed Ben Marshall, and though Leeds resisted strongly until just after the hour mark, goals by Tom Cairney, Jordan Rhodes and Jay Spearing settled the match.

Poliça's music and lyrics strike a discordant chord with Samantha Cameron's life and upbringing. The alternative group's songs feature violent imagery and radical feminist themes, which seem at odds with the politician's bohemian sensibilities.

The copper coin, which is smaller than a penny, was found in silt after the River Avon burst its banks between Bristol and Bath. The tiny coin suggests that there were links between the south west of England and the Mediterranean in the Iron Age.

Atletico Madrid's manager Diego Simeone has criticised English football for their poor showing in Europe this season, saying that Premier League sides need to wake up and improve. Simeone's side take on Real Madrid in a Champions League quarter-final second leg on Wednesday night, and he is confident that they will win.

McIlroy is currently battling a bout of flu and is uncertain if he will be able to compete in the upcoming Masters Tournament. Meanwhile, Tiger Woods is back in the mix and is looking to have a successful comeback.

The Boy Scouts of America has hired the nation's first openly gay Eagle Scout as a summer camp leader. This hire is in contrast to the national organization's ban on openly gay adult members, and advocates for letting gays participate in scouting hailed the move.

Princess Eugenie of York looked hipster chic in a striped skirt and bowler hat at a New York retail store on Thursday. The 25-year-old cousin of Princes William and Harry was seen texting on her mobile as she navigated the concrete jungle. The British royal, who is currently working in New York, showcased her hipster style for the second day in a row wearing a black Topshop skirt, black leather top and a black and cream miniskirt. Princess Eugenie, who recently turned 25, was engrossed in her phone after indulging in some retail therapy at Intermix. David Cameron has warned English voters that they have '11 days to save Britain' from a Labour administration backed by the SNP, claiming that the Scottish National Party doesn't want the country to succeed. The Prime Minister's comments come as polls indicate that the General Election race is still neck and neck, with the UK heading for a hung parliament and coalition negotiations after May 7.

PepsiCo is dropping the sweetener aspartame from its popular drink, Diet Pepsi, in the United States in response to customer feedback. The reformulated drinks will now contain sucralose, another artificial sweetener commonly known as Splenda. Aspartame has been at the center of critical reports linking it to a range of health problems, although research has shown it to be safe.

After landing a role in Gone Girl alongside industry heavyweights Ben Affleck and Rosamind Pike, Emily Ratajkowski became an object of desire for men worldwide - and women everywhere are desperate to emulate her curves. A newly unveiled set of photographs show London-born Emily, 23, showing off her enviable figure - so what's her secret? Emily's diet and exercise regime consists of carnivorous eating habits and occasional indulgence, hiking and yoga, and keeping her body healthy with fresh ingredients. Chelsea secured their Premier League title with a late winner at Loftus Road against Queens Park Rangers. Thibaut Courtois was the star of the show, producing a number of crucial saves to deny Charlie Austin and Matt Phillips. Nedum Onuoha and Matt Phillips performed well at the back, while Clint Hill and Joey Barton shone in midfield. Cesc Fabregas scored the winner in 87 minutes, to condemn QPR to a devastating defeat.

A horrific car accident involving an eight-year-old girl and her two brothers left one of the boys fighting for his life. Piper, who was traveling with her mother and grandmother, was killed in the accident.

In this fascinating video, an office worker captures his entire day with a GoPro camera, turning even the most mundane task into an adrenaline-pumping activity. The 90-second video has quickly become a hit on YouTube, with viewers praising its creative and unique take on day-to-day office life.

Gridley and Reed, their superior, orchestrated a scam to steal goods from the Asda in Basildon, Essex, where Gridley worked. They were caught after being sacked from the store, and Gridley was sentenced to 12 months in prison.

German detectives are investigating links between the Hatton Garden gems heist and a strikingly similar raid on a Berlin bank two years ago. In the Hatton Garden raid, thieves stole jewels and cash from 72 safety deposit boxes. German detectives are looking for any DNA that may have been left at the scene of the Berlin raid and are hopeful that this will help them catch the perpetrators.

Jimmy Kimmel performed the Philippines' favorite ballad Lalaban Ako Para Sa Filipino on his live show, and Manny Pacquiao had nothing but good things to say about it. The song is dedicated to Pacquiao's fellow Filipinos and was written and recorded specifically for his walk-out music when he fights Floyd Mayweather next week. Kimmel's earnest appreciation of the song and the footage of the devastating Typhoon Haiyan in the video appeared tongue-in-cheek.

Former England batsman Kevin Pietersen believes Michael Vaughan is the right man to lead England Cricket. Pietersen received the lion's share of attention during a photocall for his new club Surrey. The controversial star and Vaughan were England team-mates before Pietersen was axed by the ECB. Vaughan would be a pioneering presence, having spoken with passion and candour about the need to accept England's failings and press for change at all costs. That may yet prove good news for the exiled Pietersen.

Following the abolition of milk quotas, a price war is set to break out over the cost of milk. Smaller family businesses in the dairy industry are likely to be hardest hit, while British farmers are likely to find the price they are paid by supermarkets is driven down.

The 'Take That' pop trio have still not repaid £20million they owe the taxman, one year after they were ordered to do so. This has been criticised by The Taxpayers' Alliance, with pressure mounting further by the fact that TV sports presenter Gabby Logan has already fulfilled her promise to pay back all the money she owed from the 'tax shelter' scheme.

An undercover police officer who was captured on video ranting at an Uber driver is assigned to the Joint Terrorism Task Force. The officer is being investigated by Internal Affairs Bureau for his behavior towards the driver.

Michelle Keegan has launched a stellar fashion career since leaving the cobbled streets of Weatherfield behind. The pint-sized brunette may be busy filming for her new show, as well as modelling in her new Garnier Ambre Solaire campaign, but she's managed to fit designing a new fashion range into her hectic schedule.

Liverpool winger Raheem Sterling rejected a contract offer from the club worth £100,000-a-week and instead pointed to his desire to finish out the season before considering any more offers. Sterling's comments suggest he is not a money-grabbing 20-year-old and instead wants to focus on winning trophies with Liverpool. However, his comments also suggest that he is not opposed to a move to a bigger club in the future.

The article discusses a classic optical illusion known as the 'Marilyn Monroe effect'. This illusion occurs when a blurry picture of Marilyn Monroe is superimposed over a picture of Albert Einstein, and features with a high spatial frequency are only visible when viewing them close up. Due to vision problems, the brain is less able to pick out details in Monroe's image, and instead sees a Hollywood pin-up. This illusion can also highlight how the brain processes information, and Dr Aude Oliva's team believes hybrid images such as this may prove useful to advertisers who want to change how their logos appear at different distances.

Ian Rogers is a man who has an obsession with haunted dolls. He claims that each of his dolls has its own personality and that they are all haunted by the spirits of people who have passed on. Ian often takes his dolls to events and gets people to guess their stories. His favourite doll is Annabel, who he believes is haunted by the spirit of a seven-year-old girl who drowned.

Leigh Griffiths scores hat-trick for Celtic in comeback Premiership win over Kilmarnock, showing his desire to prove Ronny Deila wrong. The Parkhead manager praises Griffiths' contribution, and says he could be a kicker in American football. Celtic could now win the title against closest rivals Aberdeen on May 10 if both teams win all their games beforehand.
The majority of Scottish voters would rather have a referendum on the EU rather than another independence vote, according to a new survey.

The BBC filled more than half its election TV debate audience with left-leaning voters, some of whom were brought in from Scotland and Wales. The audience at the filming of Thursday night’s debate in Westminster repeatedly cheered calls for more public spending and strong defences of immigration. When Ukip leader Nigel Farage interjected and said they were prejudiced, ‘even by the Left-wing standards of the BBC’, the audience only booed him further.

Marc Carn, from Plymouth, Devon, disappeared during a stag do in Barcelona on Saturday night. After failing to turn up for his flight back home, his worried family contacted the Foreign Office in a bid to track him down. He was found safe and well this afternoon after walking for two days to get back to Barcelona.

The article discusses how a three-year-old orphaned chimpanzee was rescued after she was found in a tiny wooden box cowering from the animal traffickers who killed her mother. The traffickers had kept the terrified three-year-old in the box for two weeks and the men had been trying to find a buyer on the lucrative black market when they were stopped at a check point trying to cross into Sierra Leone from Guinea, in west Africa, last week. The chimpanzees' future looks brighter due to the fact that she was not seriously injured nor fatally traumatised and is currently being accepted by a sanctuary.

Scientists claim the computer keyboard could be a powerful new tool in their battle against Parkinson's disease. Researchers in Massachusetts believe a person's keystrokes may reveal a huge amount of information about their motor skills. Now they're working on creating a keyboard that can tell doctors if someone has the neuron impairment, simply by analysing the way they type.

David Axelrod, a US political strategist who helped mastermind Barack Obama's two presidential election victories, has admitted not paying taxes in the UK on his reported £300,000 salary. Miliband aides have expressed concerns that despite his high salary, Mr Axelrod has been 'invisible' ahead of polling day.

A military sergeant accused of raping a female cadet after telling her cousin he hoped she was as sweet as she looked is on trial. The witness testified that when she asked the sergeant to repeat what he had said, he became quiet and then hung up. The trial is expected to run for six weeks.

The article tells the story of Dr Rory Lyons, who has been suspended by the Medical Practitioners Tribunal Service and his surgery raided following four deaths. The deaths of two members of a family are at the centre of the criminal probe and detectives are also investigating the death of a retired stonemason. Relatives of the deceased say they were in complete shock when they heard about the investigations.
The article discusses how an unusually cold spring storm that has brought heavy rain and hail to parts of Northern California is a welcome respite, but will do little to ease the historic drought.

A new Ask Reddit thread invited members of the disabled community to list all the ways able-bodied people think they are being supportive, but end up being just the opposite, with many users stating that being helped is not a sign of bravery or strength, and that being patronised is insulting. Some common complaints include people insisting they 'help', taking charge of their wheelchair, and suggesting 'diets', 'remedies' or 'cures'. Religion was also mentioned as a common annoyance for disabled people.

They have replaced many stars and are now looking to win both the La Liga and the Champions League. Diego Simeone is the driving force behind this progress and fans are optimistic as long as he remains at the club.

An aftershock has caused theirprimary facility to go from a place of safety and healing to one of uncertainty and worry. Koirala's group is relying on bottled water and is now rationing food, while their "Butterfly Home" (permanent residence) has suffered extensive damage. The group deployed a medical and assessment team to aid the Nepalese people in several remote villages outside of the city. Six canine-firefighter search teams from the United States also assisted in rescue and recovery efforts. The Prime Minister has backed the royals' choice of private care for Kate's second birth, praising the NHS while insisting that people have the right to choose their treatment options.

18-year-old Ryan Hardie marked his first ever Light Blues start with a brace as Stuart McCall's side clinched a 3-1 win over Dumbarton. The teenager had made just four substitute appearances before facing the Sons at the Dumbarton Stadium, but his double put Rangers in command after they fell behind to Mark Wilson's second-minute opener. The former Celtic full-back's last goal was also against Rangers - he netted the Hoops' winner in a controversial Scottish Cup quarter-final replay at Parkhead in March 2011.

He launched into a racist tirade at white members of staff and even assaulted the headmaster. The school eventually resolved the situation with the help of the pupils' mosque.

The researchers at the Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology in Australia have developed a drone that they claim can help motivate runners to keep their pace up. The drone is designed to float in front of the runner and follow a set path and speed. The drone was successful in motivating the 13 joggers in their study to keep their pace up. There are some concerns from the runners, though, such as the quadcopters occasionally deviating from their path and wobbling in the wind. But overall, the researchers think their study could help inspire new ways to perform various physical activities.

Bristol City held on for a 3-1 victory over Preston North End to move closer to promotion to the Championship. The victory ensures Swindon Town will not be able to catch up, while also keeping Preston in third place.

In an interview with New York Times columnist Thomas Friedman, President Barack Obama defends his decision to pursue diplomacy with Iran, acknowledging that it has caused strain with the close ally. He describes the negotiations as an opportunity to take the nuclear issue off the table and believes that successful negotiations presents the most effective way to prevent Iran from obtaining a nuclear weapon.

Skopelos, a small, relaxed island off the coast of the mainland, is a popular film location for Mamma Mia!. The island's relaxed vibe is apparent in the pretty port of Chora, and in the generosity of spirit of the boat owners who gave Kyle and his girlfriend a second anchor to prevent them from sinking. The island is known as the film location for Mamma Mia!, and Kyle and his girlfriend were worried about encountering Meryl Streep's Donna all week. However, the island lies in the Sporades, east of the mainland, and most people fly to Skiathos, followed by an hour's ferry ride to Skopelos. The island has a relaxed, offbeat vibe that plays out in the pretty port of Chora, with wooded hillsides punctuated with white walls topped by terracotta-tiled roofs and a ruined Venetian fortress and dozens of chapels making you feel that this is a spiritual retreat. Many of the chapels were built by families as status symbols and are owned and maintained by their descendants, rather than by the Greek Orthodox Church. Nick Clegg will today promise the highest education spending of any party with a £5billion flagship offer to undecided voters. This is a deal-breaker in any future coalition talks after May 7, in order to win over ‘centre-ground’ Conservative voters worried about funding cuts for schools. Education is a sore point for many who backed the Lib Dems in 2010 on the promise that the party would scrap tuition fees and then saw them trebled to £9,000 per year. But Mr Clegg will claim the Lib Dems are now ‘the party of education’ and the school funding commitment is firm because it will be on the front page of today’s manifesto of pledges.

New York teen Daria Rose, who lost everything in Hurricane Sandy, has been accepted to seven Ivy League schools. Rose immersed herself in her studies after the storm and has a bright future ahead of her. The frequent moves Rose and her family underwent after the superstorm made finishing school work difficult, but she never gave up on her dream of attending an Ivy League school. Rose's essay about her experience helped her secure a spot in Yale, Harvard, Princeton, Dartmouth, University of Pennsylvania, Cornell, and Brown.

As a father, Johan Bavman found that Sweden's generous parental leave policy allowed fathers to share in the joys and struggles of raising infants. However, the photographer found that only 12% of Swedish couples equally share the 480 days of leave, with women continuing to lead the way as the stay-at-home parent and men as the careerist. To promote both parents to raise their children, Sweden has mandated that 60 of the 480 days be "daddy months" or "partner months." If the 60 daddy days aren't used, they are lost, reducing the maximum leave to 420 days. The country also created a "gender equality bonus": the more days that parents share the leave equally, they get a bonus that could total up to 1,500 euros, or $1,649. The photographer is looking for a total of 60 fathers to photograph, to culminate in an exhibition and a book.

Laura Wells spoke to Australian Women's Weekly about the extreme dieting measures taken by her model roommates to prepare for Fashion Week. The size 14 beauty lived with a group of standard 'skinnier' models during her stint working in New York, and says that their agents instructed them to stick to a diet of 'one cracker and a couple of glasses of water'. These measures went to the extremes, with no food being eaten, prescription dietary pills, and agents telling girls that they were only allowed to have one cracker and a couple glasses of water leading up to fashion week. Laura says that her model friends struggled to book jobs and living with a plus size model who was highly in-demand was comparing themselves to her.

20-year-old Liverpool winger Raheem Sterling is being ridiculed after allegedly smoking a shisha pipe. Critics say the fad is a dangerous habit and Sterling could risk damaging his health if he continues to indulge.

Harley Renshaw battled cancer using a superhero mask to feel stronger during his treatments. The young boy is now cancer-free and his parents are overjoyed. Harley's story made headlines around the world and he has now become the face of Cancer Research UK's Kids and Teens Campaign.

Raheem Sterling insists he has not been affected by the criticism of his ongoing contract stand-off with Liverpool, despite being heckled at the club's recent kit launch. The 20-year-old, speaking for the first time since his now infamous BBC interview, insists he is immune to the negative comments. Sterling is one of Europe's most sought after young players, with Manchester City, Arsenal, Chelsea and Manchester United all having a genuine interest.

After the liberation of Bergen-Belsen Concentration Camp in 1945, solicitor Cecil Hamilton-Miller was responsible for the convictions of 31 concentration camp guards. These convicted individuals include several key figures in the camp's horrific history, such as camp commander Josef Kramer and Dr Fritz Klein. Despite his honorable actions in the wake of the liberation, many family and friends had no idea of his involvement. A historic photograph of Mr Hamilton-Miller watching on as camp commander Josef Kramer, known as The Beast of Belsen, is marched to his death at gunpoint following his trial was recently discovered by his family.
Nigeria's President-elect Muhammadu Buhari has vowed to fight Boko Haram, one year after the group kidnapped nearly 300 schoolgirls. The girls remain missing and their families are still grieving.

The study also found that one breed of bird in particular, the barn swallow, had plummeted in population. The researchers are hoping to get information on the future of Fukushima from Chernobyl, which was the site of a devastating release of radioactive materials in 1986.

Ian Poulter, an English golfer, uses acupuncture to help recover from the strains of the sport. The 39-year-old posted an Instagram picture of what looked like a painful acupuncture session, with eight needles stuck in his neck, to show off his recovery. Other leading sportsmen, such as Floyd Mayweather Jnr., have also used unorthodox treatments to aid their recovery. These treatments include kriotherapy (or cryotherapy), horse placenta massages, and red wine baths.

Three men have been jailed for eight years after targeting pensioners with dementia, demanding money for bogus roof repairs. The family gang carried out 35 thefts, starting in February 2012, while the victims were still able to withdraw cash from their local Post Office.

Per Mertesacker has tipped compatriot Jurgen Klopp to make his mark in the Barclays Premier League if he opts to continue his career in England. Klopp, 47, announced earlier this week that he would end his seven-year stint at Borussia Dortmund when the current season draws to a close, prompting fresh speculation that he could head for the Premier League. Manchester City have already indicated that a man who has also been linked with Manchester United and Arsenal in the past, is not in their sights, but Germany international Mertesacker insists Klopp would be a good fit in the English top flight. Jurgen Klopp has revealed he will be vacating his role as Borussia Dortmund boss at the end of the season. Arsenal vice-captain Per Mertesacker says Klopp would be a top manager in the Premier League.

Prasanna 'Nick' Arulchelvam, 34, died after he fell from a van while chasing a gang of thieves. The man who pushed Mr Prasanna to his death was sentenced to 11 years in jail. Cousins Patrick and James O'Driscoll were both sentenced to 10-and-a-half years in jail for manslaughter after admitting to pushing Mr Prasanna to his death. McInerney, 34, who went on the run after he was arrested in December 2013 and bailed was sentenced to 11 years in jail for a total of 11 years - 10-and-a-half years for manslaughter, two years concurrent for conspiracy to steal, with six months consecutive from the suspended sentence.

Iran's nuclear program has been a defining issue of the regime of Ali Khamenei, who has refused to end uranium enrichment activities despite increasing economic pressure. In June, if negotiators succeed in completing a deal with the United States and its P5+1 partners, international investors, including Americans, would be able to invest in Iran for the first time in decades. If Khamenei approves the deal, Iranians hope their lives will improve in the post-deal era.

William Shatner has come up with a radical solution to California's drought crisis - building a pipeline from Seattle to the state. However, some experts have said his proposal is illogical and would require a lot of hurdles to be overcome.

The new chairman-elect, Colin Graves, and the new CEO, Tom Harrison, are looking for a new captain, and Cook's future as England's captain hinges on his recent performances. The article also talks about Cook's history of success as a batsman, and how he needs to start replicating that form if he wants to keep his captaincy.

Jason Holder led the West Indies to a five-day Test win over England in Antigua and Marlon Samuels showed why he is one of the game's premier batsmen by reaching 103 not out. This Test was a harder, slower-paced contest than some fans may be used to, and it was rewarding for those who stuck around for the long haul to see some excellent cricket. This win will inspire the team and help them continue to compete in the global cricketing arena.

In the process of getting out of the car the ticket they had bought fell on the floor just underneath the driver's seat - invisible to the warden who issued them with a penalty. The row escalated from an initial £25 fine to bailiffs knocking on their door and demanding £400. Mr O'Byrne, from Southsea in Portsmouth, Hampshire, was forced to pay the sum to Chichester District Council after the incident in a car park in Chichester, West Sussex.

James Milner is one of many players set to leave their Premier League clubs on a free in June. The midfielder could be a good signing for a newly-promoted side, while Aston Villa's Ron Vlaar is also in contention for a move.

The article discusses a new vaccine being developed to help prevent prostate cancer from recurring. The vaccine is designed to help the immune system recognise compounds found in prostate cancer cells, and is being given to men who have already been treated for the cancer. Researchers are testing the vaccine as a way to treat cancer that has returned, but if successful, the vaccine could be used as a first line treatment for prostate and potentially breast cancer in the future.

The Green party has released a new election advert featuring David Cameron, Nick Clegg, Ed Miliband and Nigel Farage forming a bizarre pro-austerity boyband. The video is designed to show that despite their claims to the contrary, the Tories, Lib Dems, Labour and Ukip are all singing the same tune on cuts, public services and immigration.

Mindy Kaling's brother Vijay Chokalingam recently revealed a project of his own, and while it has been getting a lot of attention, it hasn't generated quite as many laughs - either from observers or from her famous sibling. Chokalingam posed as a black man to gain admission to medical school, but his scheme was exposed after the statute of limitations expired. Chokalingam claims that affirmative action is only a form of "systematic racism," but when all is said and done, it offers very little evidence of the "privilege" that he claims is accorded to black, Hispanic and Native American candidates. His scheme received widespread criticism, and he is now writing a book about his experiences.

The article discusses recent research that has found that sweet potatoes contain "foreign DNA" that has been altered through natural genetic modification. Sweet potatoes are a major crop plant that is consumed around the world, and this discovery suggests that the plant has been modified for thousands of years. The research raises the question of how we can trust the safety of GM foods, as the process of natural genetic modification is not under our control.

The Taliban's "Cultural Commission" released a biography of its leader, Mullah Mohammed Omar, on the movement's website, purportedly to dispel rumors of his death. The biography describes Omar's early years and his role in the Afghan resistance against the Soviet Union and later against the Taliban's post-9/11 overthrow by a U.S.-backed coalition of Afghan fighters.

Helen Dunn, 78, found out she starred on the cover of a raunchy lads' mag from 1955 when she opened a copy of the Sunday Mercury newspaper. The mother-of-two and grandmother from Stourbridge, West Midlands, was flicking through the newspaper when she spotted herself on the cover of a raunchy lads' mag from 1955. Dunn admits that she was shocked to see the images and recalls her modelling days with a fondness.

Tony Blair's statements in Newsweek about wanting to set up a "leaders club" of former state leaders and dismissing the need for democracy has caused some controversy. Tories MP Andrew Bridgen has called him a "megalomaniac" and believes he has "completely lost the plot".

After an employee clicked on a link in an email, their family-friendly coffee shop's Facebook page was hacked and flooded with pornography. After Facebook failed to respond to multiple reports of inappropriate content, Scooter's Coffee was able to contact larger businesses who were able to remove the content and restore the page.

Adam McBurney, a young Irish rugby star, escaped serious injury when his home was targeted by a gunman who fired multiple bullets through his windows. The attack has left the player's brother Shane, 20, and neighbours worried for his safety. Police are investigating the incident as having criminal elements.

The Dove One Beautiful Thought campaign encourages women to be kinder to themselves and each other by speaking their thoughts honestly and openly. Two actresses read the raw and honest comments women have about themselves out loud, in a cafe, to unsuspecting participants. Many of the comments written in the notebooks, when said out loud, underline the way many women are effectively bullying themselves every single day by focusing on their insecurities and never their beauty. The campaign is yet another in Dove's line of powerful videos, which all aim to encourage women to be kinder to themselves and each other.

Christian Benteke saved Aston Villa from relegation with a hat-trick against QPR on Saturday, clinching a point that keeps the club in the Premier League. Benteke's first-half double and a goal in the second half from Matt Phillips saw Villa take a 2-1 lead at the break, but QPR hit back with two goals in the second half. Benteke's third and final goal of the game clinched a 3-3 draw and kept Villa in the Premier League.

Gareth Huw Davies enjoys his trip to Sri Lanka, where he finds much to admire in the island's serene landscapes and ancient civilisations. Davies particularly enjoys spending time exploring the tea plantations and enjoying the company of the island's animals. Davies recommends that visitors not miss out on visiting the Uda Walawe nature reserve, the Temple of the Tooth, and Trincomalee.

The England cricket team is under pressure from the media and the public to win the Grenada Test and the Barbados Test. Coach Peter Moores insists that captain Alastair Cook is a very good player and that Trott is ready to play. The England cricket team is facing a potential losing streak if they don't win these last two Tests.

University of Brighton student, Janet Muller, was last seen in Portslade on the night before she was found dead in the boot of a burning car. Police have now released video stills and footage of the 21-year-old in the area on the night before her death.

The couple that decorated their home with trinkets and memorials that were looted from graves have been banned from cemeteries indefinitely. Sean Jefferson, 45, and Elizabeth Jowitt, 37, admitted handling stolen goods at York Magistrates' Court after decorating their flat with items such as lanterns, wreaths, and trinkets. The couple's actions were eventually discovered when a relative of one of the victims noticed a heart-shaped wreath which was meant for her mother hanging in their home. She contacted police and a raid found further items such as love heart ornaments, rosary beads and handmade gifts being used as decorations.
